text: John Steele (April 9, 1909 - June 7, 1996) was an American ski jumper. Steele was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, and moved with his family to Steamboat Springs, Colorado in 1918. When he was 12 he ski jumped at the local Winter Carnival, and continued to jump at the carnival for 20 years. While employed shovelling snow off a bank roof, he built a ski jump on the bank, which he used until the sheriff made him stop because of fears he would jump in front of passing traffic.2018/19 Steamboat Press Kit, Steamboat Resort, p. 76 In 1924 he broke the world record in ski jumping for boys 14 and under. He went on to attend the University of Denver, where he founded the Pioneer Ski Club.John Steele, Colorado Snowsports Museum Hall of Fame Steele was selected as a member of the U.S. team for the 1932 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, New York and competed in the ski jumping individual event there."Local ski riders in U. S. Olympic Games team", Steamboat Pilot, January 29, 1932, p. 8 ==References== Category:1909 births Category:1996 deaths Category:American male ski jumpers Category:Olympic ski jumpers of the United States Category:Ski jumpers at the 1932 Winter Olympics Category:Sportspeople from Minneapolis
title: John Steele (ski jumper)
